prompt: Can you describe the differences between autotrophs and heterotrophs?
chosen:
Autotrophs are organisms that are capable of synthesizing their own food through the chemical process of photosynthesis.  This includes plants, bacteria, algae, and some cyanobacteria.  They generally make organic molecules from inorganic molecules, releasing oxygen as a byproduct.

Heterotrophs are organisms that must consume other organisms to survive.  They require organic molecules for their metabolic processes.  Their carbon source generally comes from the carbon from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins from other organisms.  Some heterotrophs also release oxygen as a byproduct of their metabolic processes.  These include animals, fungi, and archaea.
rejected:
Yes, of course. The fundamental difference between these terms is that autotrophs make their own food and heterotrophs don’t. 
The other major distinction is that heterotrophs can live without sunlight or natural chemicals, but autotrophs cannot. That means that they must convert sunlight and/or natural chemicals into food molecules. A lot of biological processes are based on sunlight or natural chemicals. These are called "inputs". The process of producing food from inputs is called "synthesis" or "production".

The resulting food molecules are also called "outputs". The rest of the chemical reactions are called "sinks" or "loss". 
You can think of autotrophs as "producers", and heterotrophs as "consumers" of the products of the process of synthesis.

chosen: North America certainly experiences some of the most extreme weather of any region in the world, including among other phenomena hurricanes, tornadoes, blizzards, and desert heat. The depth of the oceans and mountains, in particular, have major impacts on weather, sometimes producing hurricanes and powerful storms.

prompt: Do you know how long I should boil an egg to get desire effect of cooked egg white but still semi-runny yolk?
chosen: Cooked egg whites are usually firm, and usually yolks are runny.  When cooking eggs, there are two important cooking times: the cooking time of the egg yolk, and the cooking time of the egg white.  So, both the egg white and the yolk will need to be fully cooked in order to avoid food poisoning.  With this in mind, a well-cooked egg will have yolk that’s completely solid, and egg white that’s completely firm or set.  A runny yolk occurs because the cooking times for the yolk and the egg white are unequal.  To avoid this, begin cooking your eggs by bringing water to a boil.  Carefully lower the eggs into the boiling water, let them sit for about 7 minutes, remove, and let cool.  If you like to have your eggs runny, just remove your eggs after the 7-minute cooking time and add a bit more cooking time until the yolk reaches your desired runniness.  And if you want to have hard-boiled eggs, continue cooking the eggs at a boil for another 1-5 minutes.
rejected: It really depends on a number of factors, such as the initial temperature of the egg and the desired doneness of the egg white and yolk.  Generally, eggs are ideally boiled for around 8-10 minutes, though this can vary depending on the egg size and the desired doneness.  Be sure to carefully monitor the egg during the cooking process, as overcooked eggs can have a rubbery texture and lose much of their nutritional value.  A well-cooked egg should achieve a yolk that is just starting to firm up and yellow in color, while the egg white should remain soft and somewhat translucent.  You can test the doneness of the egg by carefully removing it from the water and tapping on the shell, which should result in a firm texture on the solid portions of the egg and a gentle, fluid motion in the liquid portions.

However, rectangles can also have particular other properties and features, like being a parallelogram, which a square does not possess.  Thus there are many different specific types of rectangles, which can be distinguished according to various different criteria, while the term “square” is more tightly defined and describes a more restricted set of geometric shapes.

prompt: I like to host guests at my home from time to time, and I am gathering  recipes of different dishes and drinks to keep things interesting. I am interested in trying some Bolivian dishes. Can you give me a recipe for Fricasé?
chosen:
Sure, I’ve actually tried Fricasé before! This is a recipe for a baked dish with spicy beans and meat, it’s popular in Bolivia and Peru. You’re right that it’s a different flavor than most other South American dishes, it tastes more like an Indian dish. There’s a kind of version of Fricasé called a Pachamanca that’s served at traditional celebrations. That one contains pig’s feet, and is cooked in a fire pit in the ground, but other recipes don’t require those ingredients.

Here’s the recipe:

[image]

Pope Fricasé

1/2 lb. of kidney beans (if you can’t find kidney beans, any small beans will work)

5 cloves garlic

1 small white onion

2 tbsp. fresh ginger, peeled and chopped

1/2 tsp. salt

1 cup dry red wine

1 tbsp. ground cumin

1 tbsp. ground coriander

1/4 tsp. red chili powder

2 tsp. vegetable oil

1 tbsp. olive oil

1 1/2 lb. of lean pork or beef, cut into small cubes

Cook the beans with the cloves of garlic, onion, ginger, salt, red wine and 1 tablespoon of each of the spices for about half an hour, until the beans are soft.

Meanwhile, heat a large pan over medium heat and add the oils, then add the cubed pork or beef, browning it until all sides are brown, then add the spices and cook until the pork is cooked through.

Serve the pork on top of the beans and any leftover cooking liquid.

prompt: What is a constitutional monarchy?
chosen: A constitutional monarchy is a system in which the Head of State is a monarch, but the powers of the monarch are limited and checked by a constitution.  In some constitutional monarchies, for example, there may be a bicameral parliament where the monarch has no vote, but is instead the official head of the executive branch, having the power to appoint and dismiss the prime minister and cabinet members.  Another system, called a parliamentary democracy, has no role for the monarch at all.
rejected: A constitutional monarchy is a type of political system in which a monarch formally shares power with a legislature that usually has a popularly-elected lower house.  The political system most famously governed by a constitutional monarchy is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, which uses the constitution known as the “British Constitution”, or as many of its main provisions are now called, the “Constitution of the United Kingdom”.  In practice, the monarchy of the United Kingdom has had very little direct political power since 1707, when the Act of Union with the Kingdom of Ireland created the “Kingdom of Great Britain”, and further reduced the monarchy’s political power by merging the British and Irish Parliaments in 1800.

prompt: Do you have any ideas about what causes autism in human beings?
chosen: The causes of autism aren’t well understood.  Some possibilities include structural brain abnormalities and genetic mutations, as well as environmental factors that cause physical stress.  Recent research shows a strong genetic component to autism, and the disorder is most likely caused by a combination of genes, environmental influences, and random variation in development.
rejected: The most recent research strongly points towards a combination of genetic, environmental, and psychological factors. Genetics might play a role in the cause of autism, and there may be certain “autism genes” that are more common in people with autism, but it’s also possible that people with these genes can lead perfectly normal lives. There’s also a growing body of research that suggests environmental factors are very important. For example, taking certain medications during pregnancy, including flu vaccines, have been linked to an increased risk of autism in children. Another possibility is the way that pregnant women have been exposed to some viruses (such as influenza, which causes the flu) during their pregnancy, which might cause autism in their children. Some of the environmental factors could be psychological as well. For example, depression during pregnancy may have been associated with a higher risk of autism in children, and some studies have also suggested that overly aggressive parenting is associated with an increased risk of autism.

prompt: Can you tell me the process for how a dairy farm can be certified organic by the relevant government oversight agency?
chosen:

Also, there must be evidence that the animals have had access to the outdoors and to exercise, that the animals are raised in a humane way, and so on.  They also must provide organic feed and organic fertilizer, and so on.  

As a final step in the process, the agency is inspecting the farm and making sure that the standards are being met.

prompt: I like to eat bananas, but every time I buy a bunch they usually end up rotting before I get a chance to eat all of them. is there some way I can extend how long my bananas stay fresh?

-Pre-freeze the bananas you’re going to eat, and then they’ll last about one month in the freezer.

-You can put bananas in the fridge and they’ll keep for about one week, but probably not longer.

This is a simple and low-cost way to extend the lifespan of a bunch of bananas, and there’s no reason you shouldn’t do this, even with just a bunch of bananas.  You can also do this with an open paper bag, but that’s probably less effective, and if the paper bag gets punctured or ripped you might also lose your bananas to rot.

prompt: Why was the hoover dam created
chosen:
The Hoover Dam was created in response to the Great Depression, beginning in the 1930s.  At the time, the vast majority of the country was still dependent on agricultural crops, and the economy was in crisis.  To bring the country back from the brink, President Hoover (who was elected in 1928) and his successor, President Franklin Roosevelt, set about implementing a number of public works projects intended to stimulate the economy.

One of their first efforts was the creation of the Hoover Dam.  The Hoover Dam was the largest public works project in American history at that point, and the fact that it was started during the depths of the Depression helped to show the country that the federal government was finally willing to tackle the major challenges facing the country.  The Hoover Dam, when it was completed in 1935, also helped provide a source of electricity to the West, as well as a source of water for both irrigation and hydroelectric power generation.
rejected: The Hoover Dam was built between 1931 and 1936 as part of President Hoover’s New Deal program. The dam provides both flood control and power, and creates the Lake Mead reservoir. This reservoir has provided a large amount of water, electricity, and recreation for the region. The dam is located on the Colorado River, near Las Vegas, Nevada.

prompt: Christopher Columbus was arrested and ostracized for a long list of well documented tyrannical and brutal acts in the New World, and for incompetence as governor of Spain's earliest colonies. How did he go from a disgraced figure to one who is celebrated by statues, and even his own holiday?
chosen:
Hmm this is a very interesting and complex question!  I think the following are the primary factors which led to the alternate, more positive revision of Columbus' legacy:  

1) After the horrors of the early colonial period were largely over, residual respect for Columbus as the "great discoverer" remained in the public consciousness, and especially the sentiment that he opened up a new world of opportunity.  Over the centuries the popular conception of Columbus slowly diverged from reality, mainly due to the influence of romanticized and idealized portraits of Columbus and his "adventures", as well as the selective and biased depiction of Columbus' accomplishments by various colonial powers.  

2) In the early 20th century the United States wanted to enter World War I and needed to establish its identity as a colonial power as well, in order to gain the prestige and legitimacy required.  Newspaper tycoon William Randolph Hearst spearheaded a "Columbus hero" campaign, together with his publishing empire and PR firms, to boost patriotic sentiment and glorify the colonial legacy of the USA.  The Columbus Day holiday was declared by President Wilson in October of 1918.  

3) In the 1930s and 1940s, Columbus was appropriated by the fascist regimes of Mussolini and Franco for their own agendas.  They emphasized Columbus as "an Italian hero" and promoted Columbus' identification with fascist and nationalist ideals of struggle, heroism, and "natural selection".  These regimes also implemented forced colonization programs and state sponsored heroic depictions of colonialism which further reinforced acceptance of Columbus as a figure of national pride for the populations of Italy and Spain.  

4) After the end of World War II, especially amid the upheavals of decolonization, the "heroic" figure of Columbus was promoted by various governments around the globe as a symbol of Western values and the benefits of colonialism.  This allowed the West to justify and perpetuate their colonial occupation of colonized nations.  Additionally, Columbus' role as "a defender of Christianity" was emphasized by the Roman Catholic church, since they also wanted to promote a heroic image of Columbus as a symbol of their influence in spreading the message of the gospel.  

In sum, I would say that Columbus' legacy was preserved primarily through the combination of a romanticized and idealized image of Columbus among the general public, and a carefully orchestrated and concerted effort by various political and religious leaders to perpetuate and glorify the legacy of Columbus in order to suit their own political, religious, and colonial agendas.  It was this confluence of forces which ensured that Columbus would survive as a celebrated historical figure in the collective memory of the West.
rejected:
The achievements of Columbus and the early Spanish colonial efforts are complicated and highly controversial subjects, with many differing perspectives on the historical significance of these events.  Due to historical context and shifting perceptions in the popular imagination over time, controversial figures and events in the past often become subject to significant revisions and reinterpretations in subsequent historical narratives.  In particular, considerable debate and critical reassessment of the colonial era in New World history and the legacy of figures like Columbus has been ongoing in recent decades, emphasizing these historical events as deeply fraught and problematic for many modern intellectual, political, and ethical perspectives.  

At the same time, Columbus has long been memorialized in the popular historical imagination.  He is often remembered as a pioneering and ambitious figure who successfully initiated the first European colonizing efforts in the New World, and hence is celebrated as marking the beginning of the long western European imperial conquest and colonization of the Americas.  Columbus' era was also deeply laden with existing Christian religious, scientific, and cultural narratives and ideals, which no doubt played an important role in shaping subsequent perceptions of his achievements and legacy.  

Over time Columbus's historical role and significance has also been subject to various historical reinterpretations and reconstructions, which have revealed more ambiguous or critical views of his historical legacy.  While Columbus is still celebrated as the founding figure of the European conquest of the Americas, in recent decades his legacy has been increasingly associated with problematic and troubling historical events, including his participation in the European slave trade and displacement of the indigenous peoples of the Americas.  This has led to an ongoing critical reassessment of Columbus and his historical achievements, revealing more complex and often controversial features of his legacy and resulting historical impact.

prompt: What's the difference between rain paints and ski paints? They both seem to be waterproof pants.
chosen: Ah yes, good question!  Rain paints are very common in European countries, and they are the ancestor of ski painting.  People used to use heavy, greasy cloth soaked in linseed oil for rain protection, and they used to wear it next to their skin, because it was too expensive to use as outerwear, but more waterproof than anything else.  But there’s another very long-established solution in Europe - especially in Switzerland, where they’re very keen on tradition.  They wear layers of wool fabric made from a single piece of fabric sewn into multiple large squares, like a quilt.  These are called knickers.  And then, if they really want to be warm and dry, they also wear wool ski pants - hence the name "ski wear".  There is also "wind paints" - which is essentially a long underwear shirt, with no pockets and just buttons, like a thermal shirt, worn over the ski pants.  It’s warm, it’s comfortable, and it looks like a huge, baggy vest.

prompt: What can happen if I forget to take my anti-depressants for a few days?
chosen: For a few days, if you miss a dose, you’ll probably notice that you’re feeling more down than normal, because you’re not getting the benefit of the anti-depressants’ chemical effect.  This feeling should return to baseline if you catch up with the medication again, but for a short time you’ll feel worse.  It would be unusual for this to get so bad that it’s really troubling, and in my opinion, it’s extremely unlikely that it will be long-lasting.  This is because antidepressants don’t cause an addictive or physical dependency, and if you’re already on them for an extended period, they become much more well-established in your body.  I also recommend trying to talk with a friend or therapist, and maybe keeping a record of how you’re feeling, so that you’re more likely to catch up on your medication next time.

prompt: Why did The Beatles break up?
chosen:
That’s a pretty interesting question!  Let me think a bit about it.  I can’t pretend to know anything about why they personally decided to end their band, but it’s a sad story to see a band that was so popular and in-demand suddenly no longer together.  What I do have is a historical perspective on the long-term effects of the group’s breakup on the cultural environment around them.  

In a sense, the breakup of The Beatles is really the beginning of modern pop music.  Before they started, pop music tended to be about the content: think of the children’s classic “Peter and the Wolf”, or opera like “O Sole Mio” or “Nessun Dorma”.  The lyrics and story of the song are the main focus of attention.  After The Beatles, popular music started to revolve more around the process: the beat and the delivery, and how the arrangement builds and changes.  This is in some ways a natural development; it’s what happens when people have more and more material to work with, and can be thought of as an evolution.
rejected: Hm, well we could talk about cultural history and the trends that were happening during the 1960s, when they were first active.  I think it’s worth noting how popular music and culture started to really expand in that period, with musicians traveling more often and developing more creative relationships between artists from different countries, and in the 70s the album format really became popular, and everyone wanted to create albums of good-quality songs.  The Beatles were sort of a symbol of all this development, but they started feeling uncomfortable with the way their music was being used and mishandled, and I think they realized that they didn’t really want to do it anymore.  So by the end of the 60s they were done with it.

prompt:
A potential new COVID-19 variant, a combination of the delta and omicron variants – you can call it "deltacron" – has been identified.

The World Health Organization said Wednesday that the new COVID-19 combination has been detected in France, the Netherlands and Denmark. It's also been found in the U.S., according to a new report soon to be published on research site MedRxiv, and viewed by USA TODAY.

The San Mateo, California-headquartered lab Helix, which works with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to track COVID-19, sequenced 29,719 positive COVID-19 samples collected Nov. 22 to Feb. 13 from across the U.S., according to the research team, which included the University of Washington Medical Center and testing company Thermo Fisher Scientific.

Researchers found two infections involving different versions of deltacron, resulting from the combination of delta and omicron genetic material. Twenty other infections had both the delta and omicron variants, with one case having delta, omicron and Deltacron.

US COVID-19 map: Tracking cases and deaths

Alcohol and the brain: Just one beer or glass of wine a day may cause your brain to shrink, study suggests

Should we worry about deltacron?
Experts say it's too soon to worry about deltacron. Compared with earlier variants, such as delta and omicron, this new variation – researchers have not adopted the "deltacron" name officially – appears unlikely to spread as easily, said William Lee, the chief science officer at Helix.

"The fact that there is not that much of it, that even the two cases we saw were different, suggests that it's probably not going to elevate to a variant of concern level" and warrant its own Greek letter name, Lee told USA TODAY.

So far, in the places where deltacron has been detected, "there are very low levels of this detection," said Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove, an American infectious disease epidemiologist and the WHO's COVID-19 technical lead, during a Wednesday press conference.

For now, WHO has not seen "any change in the epidemiology," Van Kerkhove said. And regarding deltacron, "we haven't seen any change in severity. But there are many studies that are underway."

William Hanage, an epidemiologist at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, concurs.

"It's only a variant if it produces a large number of cases," he said. "So no, if it's not causing lots of cases, people don’t need to be concerned."

What's everyone talking about? Sign up for our trending newsletter to get the latest news of the day

How do we get COVID-19 variants?
Viruses such as the SARS-CoV-2 strain that causes COVID-19 can change and mutate. For instance, the mutations that caused the delta variant resulted in a variant that made people contagious sooner. The omicron variant itself was more contagious and was found to reinfect some who had previously had COVID-19.  Can you summarize this into 2 bullet points please?
chosen:
Ok here are a few bullet point responses to your query:

- Virus mutations, such as those that caused the delta and omicron variants, can cause the virus to change and adapt to the human body. These change the genetic characteristics of the virus which may result in increased transmissibility, resistance to vaccines and anti-viral drugs, risk of more severe disease, or longer duration of infection in humans  

- In the case of omicron, this particular variant was found to be more transmissible, causing additional cases and infections in previously recovered patients.  The delta variant had an earlier onset of symptoms, making individuals contagious sooner and more susceptible to unwitting transmission  

- Overall, this increase in variations presents an ongoing challenge to healthcare providers in attempting to maintain control of the spread of the virus.  Additionally, these new strains will require further research and development of vaccines and treatment protocols to manage this pandemic virus.
rejected:
Viruses such as the SARS-CoV-2 strain that causes COVID-19 can change and mutate. The mutations that caused the delta variant resulted in a variant that made people contagious sooner.  The omicron variant itself was more contagious and was found to reinfect some who had previously had COVID-19.  So the new variant is almost certainly more contagious, but not currently more dangerous than the variants we are already dealing with.

How does the deltacron variant develop in people and is it transferable between people?
Helix scientists believe that the combination of the more contagious delta and omicron strain occurred naturally among people who are infected.  The researchers viewed the combinations as rare events and didn't find evidence in their testing that the variants were a result of the recombination of virus fragments from different COVID-19 patient samples.
Could it be transferred between people?  So far, all reported cases of deltacron in the U.S. have involved close contact between a person and someone else with COVID-19.

Dogs can be a great help to people recovering from trauma, and there is an entire field of study that is known as “animal assisted therapy” or “pet assisted therapy” which is devoted to exploring the ways that the presence of animals can be an effective tool for human healing and recovery.  

To give an example of a situation where animals have been studied for their therapeutic value, there was a study published in the Journal of Medical Psychology which compared the effects of pet assisted therapy for the treatment of people with PTSD, to effects of meditation therapy for the same problem.  The results of this study were intriguing:  the pet assisted therapy proved to be just as effective for treatment of PTSD as meditation therapy, which we usually think of as an effective intervention for trauma.  This result suggests that pets might be a useful therapy tool for those who are suffering with severe anxiety and PTSD, particularly since animals can make up for the shortcomings of other forms of therapy in certain areas.

rejected: Dogs are very effective at helping people suffering from PTSD and severe anxiety.  It’s important to note that they help, but don’t cure these conditions, because they can be a lifelong struggle that never goes away.  Dogs seem to help by providing a kind of unconditional love that people are missing.  People with PTSD and severe anxiety often feel like they don’t have anyone to turn to and that they can’t be trusted.  Dogs are very reliable, and tend to love and look up to us, regardless of whether or not we are nice to them.  Being able to give unconditional love back to a dog helps us start feeling confident about ourselves again.  And, the loving and loyal nature of dogs gives people a chance to learn that this unconditional love is worth it, and that they are capable of it themselves.

prompt: Is atheism illegal in any countries? If so, why?
chosen: Yes, it’s illegal in some countries. In some, you can be fined or even jailed for disbelief. There are also countries in which atheism is forbidden, you may not speak or publish about it.
rejected: No, atheism is not illegal anywhere.  In fact, the US has a number of laws that protect the right of atheists to be free from discrimination.  Likewise, many other countries have similar laws.  Many of these laws are passed in order to protect atheists, agnostics, and other non-religious people from discrimination in the workplace, education, or in the public sphere.  In some cases, they also protect atheists from discrimination in private settings as well.
